Sometimes, it can be difficult to think of ways we can support others through communication and validate their experience. So, I wanted to share a few examples. 

Validation shows the other person that you believe their experience or statement and you do not intend to change their view or correct them for being "wrong". It's also about showing someone you heard them and can understand why they are feeling the way they do. 

Now, of course, there are caveats. These statements are probably not a good way to support someone who was in the wrong and needs to take accountability for it. They may lead to enabling in this case. However, sometimes, people just need to rant and saying 'that sounds hard' or 'seems like you had a really difficult day' can feel like a hug. 

What else would you add to this list?

I hope you are enjoying these communication series. I received a few requests to write a post on the topic specifically. Hopefully you find it helpful.

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

#communication #validation

In this post are habits, behaviours, and beliefs that negatively affect relationship (with partner, family, friends, coworkers). If overlooked, these things can have a compound effect and may lead to resentment, distress, and in some cases, a loss of that relationship. 

It’s important to understand that most of us will engage in or experience one or more of these things at some point in our relationships, especially the ones with people we feel closest to. What matters here is what you do next once you know the problem exists. It takes both parties to make things work, but both have to be willing. 

What else would you add to this list? 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Please note: This does not apply to abusive and one-sided relationships. I encourage you to use the information I share on here as a guide. Everyone’s experience is unique so some strategies/tools might not be relevant to your specific situation. See disclaimer in my highlights.

I became serious about prioritizing rest when my mind and body forcefully shut down. The days seemed blurred and everything had started to feel like a chore, even things I used to look forward to. I found myself escaping emails, deadlines, and withdrawing from others.

I kept pushing through the blaring signs of physical fatigue and mental exhaustion until I couldn’t avoid it. I pride myself in being disciplined, competitive, and driven. But one day, I noticed all I had was discipline. My drive and competitiveness had significantly reduced. I was still waking up early and working the same amount of time. But my ability to work was not the same. I also began to neglect moving my body which I try to prioritize regularly. I just did not feel like myself. 

I learned I was burnt out and was dealing with the cognitive, emotional, and physical repercussions. This is when I recognized that there is a fine balance between challenging myself to the limit and pushing past my breaking point. If I go too long without breaks, eventually my mind and body will make me take one. 

 If you are in this phase of life currently, I encourage you to strategically make time for rest and play. Don’t ignore the warning signs. Try to prioritize these three things: sleep early so you can get at least 7 hours in, take breaks frequently throughout your work day and try to stretch or walk during this time, make time for things that bring you joy at least 3 times a week.

Opportunities to rest, recharge, and move are available to us. We just choose not to take them. Chasing perfection at the cost of complete exhaustion is not worth it. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

#burnout

Setting clear boundaries let's people know your limits, your non-negotiables and what you will and will not tolerate. 

Holidays can be a stressful in terms of social commitments and navigating family dynamics. To ensure you don’t get overwhelmed or burned out, it may be helpful to set boundaries around things and behaviours that leave you feeling depleted or disrespected. In this post, my friend and licensed clinical social worker, Christine @christineguzmanlcsw share with you some examples of boundaries with family and friends during the holiday season. 

Setting boundaries can feel uncomfortable at first however the more you practice stating your boundaries out loud the less threatened you'll feel communicating them to others.  Setting boundaries protects your wellbeing, health, burnout and gets your needs met. It also helps reduce suppressed emotions like guilt, anger, resentment. 

Considerations to take into account is when there is a safety issue involved. Always assess your safety first. If  you set a boundary and the conversation escalates, retreat for safety. Every situation is different. You know best. 

We hope this helps and encourage you to save it as a resource for communicating boundaries with friends and family. 

Happy Holidays ♥️

#boundaries #communication #relationships

Motivation is the force that drives our behavior in pursuit of a goal. In this post, I share how we can leverage dopamine to maintain ongoing motivation. 

Have you tried setting incremental goals before? Did that increase your motivation to keep progressing towards it?

In my next few posts, I will be sharing more on motivation and goal-directed behavior. I hope you find it helpful. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

When I started my doctoral program, I really struggled with making time out for myself. There was always something that needed to get done and I was learning to juggle multiple demands at one time. I noticed that if I did anything for myself, such as going to the gym or  catching up with a friend, I’d feel guilty about not using that time to do work. 7 years in, there is still always something that needs to get done, but my mindset has changed. I no longer feel guilty for doing things that bring me joy and/or improve my health. 

Although making an effort to be productive and effective with our work is beneficial and helpful, it is just as important to be aware of how our pursuit for productivity is impacting us negatively. 

When this happens, I encourage you to use the strategies and reminders I’ve shared in this post to ground yourself and bounce back from this mindset. 

Join my newsletter - Psychology Snippets: I’d love for you to subscribe to my free newsletter where I share applicable strategies to improve our psychological health. You will also get my self-actualization journal when you sign up! I hope you find it helpful. (The link is in my bio)

Do you have productivity guilt? Does it motivate you to work harder or leave you exhausted? How do you manage it? 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

How did you focus on yourself this year? 

Below are a few ways I focused on myself in 2022. I love learning how people intentionally prioritize self-growth - it is always inspiring and encouraging. I hope this post does the same for you. 

1. I mindfully chose rest over a false sense of urgency by scheduling it in my days. I used to keep telling myself things will slow down next week or next month. But I’ve learned things will definitely not slow down unless I change something. I began setting more boundaries, saying no to opportunities when I had enough on my plate, and prioritizing rest.

2. I stopped caring too much about what others think of me. Other people’s opinions are based on their biased perspectives and beliefs. It is important to view these opinions objectively and consider their validity. When someone tells me I can’t do something,I ask myself: does this person have the life I am trying to achieve? 

3. I read one self-help book guide every week to gain knowledge to improve my health and habits. When it comes to non-fiction books, I like to read a detailed summary on Shortform before purchasing and diving into a full length book. This allows me to decide whether I will enjoy and benefit from the book. Sometimes the key points in the detailed summary is all I am looking for. 

P.S. you can still get your 5 day free trial when you sign up using my link shortform.com/thebraincoach (it’s also in my bio). I’ve been using Shortform for almost a year now. It has been a great resource to learn topics related to psychology, productivity, and relationships. I’m proud to be their long term partner because I use their platform almost everyday. It is definitely worth checking out. 

4. I re-evaluated the relationships in my life causing me stress, disappointment, or heartache. This led to creating connections rooted in love and understanding. But it also led to loss. 

5. I started practicing mindfulness meditation in the mornings for 20 minutes. I’ve found this practice helps me start the day with gratitude, boosts my mood, and leads to a increased focus throughout the day. I love using Insight Timer app for free guided meditations. 

Love, Nawal ♥️

Our brain's autopilot system is unconscious and fast. It allows us to make quick everyday decisions and makes room to learn new information and skills (i.e. habit formation and neuroplasticity). 

However, if not monitored, our autopilot brain can take over and make us 'complacent' and/or 'lazy'. 

To prevent the brain from functioning on autopilot completely, it is important that we become aware of our habits, behaviors, and thought patterns and change the ones that do not serve our growth. Important note: autopilot is not a mental health disorder. It is a human behavior that I believe is important to understand so we can utilize it to our advantage and understand when it’s leading to self-sabotage. 

P.S. the next issue of my free newsletter, Psychology Snippets, will also have more information on this topic. You can sign up using the link in my bio.

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

#autopilot #neuroscience #neuropscyhology

Researchers have found that procrastination is not a time-management issue but more of a self-regulation problem.

We procrastinate when we are unable to manage negative feelings around a task (such as boredom, anxiety, insecurity, frustration, resentment, and self-doubt). This is especially true when we have “task aversion”. Maybe the task is too boring or maybe it is really complex and that stresses you out. You want to avoid negative feelings when you think about the task, so you might open up Pinterest or go on a YouTube spiral instead. 

To make things worse, when we are under distress, the rational part of the brain (i.e. the prefrontal cortex) shuts down and the amygdala (the part of the brain that moderates our fear response) perceives the task as a genuine threat to our self-esteem or our mental health. This is known as the amygdala hijack and it’s a time when we are most prone to putting off the task because our brains are more concerned about removing the threat in the present moment (leading to avoidance behaviours). 

The 10 minute rule is a helpful way to minimize procrastination and take action before our emotions and brain talk us out of doing it. 

If you are enjoying my content, you might enjoy my newsletter, Psychology Snippets, where I share mental wellness information, productivity tips, and applicable strategies to improve our psychological health (link is in my bio).

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ❤️

#procrastination #productivity

You cannot expect different results if you keep repeating the same patterns over and over again. This applies to career goals, relationships, and health goals.

It is important to understand ways you’re self-sabotaging and make the effort to change these habits and behaviours.

One way we self-sabotage is by setting goals that are too overwhelming and demanding for our brain. This results in us not being able to follow through with these goals, so we start to fall back into subconscious patterns and criticize ourselves - “I will never be able to do this” “I am not good enough” “I am a failure”. ⠀
⠀
This form of mental resistance makes us feel guilty, ashamed, and unworthy. Consequently, we lose confidence in ourselves and start to make excuses for our self-sabotaging behavior - “this is just who I am” “I always do this so might as well just accept it now”. Basically, we sabotage our goals by convincing ourselves that we are fine by not doing them - we make excuses for ourselves. ⠀
⠀
Sometimes, our inner critic becomes so loud that no forms of affirmations or positive thoughts work. This is when it is important to change our goals and priorities and act on them in an achievable way (most important part). Start with small, achievable goals until you start to trust yourself again. Let your progress be messy but keep going. Consider it a victory when you achieve that goal and try not to be too hard on yourself if you miss it on an odd day. Focus on the progress. One day, you will look back and realize how much these small daily promises to yourself have changed your life. 

Ask yourself: What is a goal I want to work towards in 2023? What small steps can I take to achieve this goal? Try to make these small steps specific, achievable, and time-bound (i.e. give yourself a deadline - but with some flexibility). And most importantly, get started 🙌🏼

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

#goalsetting #progressisprogress

It can be hard to be around family members who invalidate or belittle you. It can also be hard to avoid them during the holiday season. 

Emotional invalidation can be difficult to respond to, especially when the speaker is trying to support and mean well. They may not be consciously trying to minimize your feelings but it is important to stand up for yourself when you feel dismissed. The statements in this post can help with this. 

Invalidating the feelings of a person sends the message that their thoughts and emotions are not important or valid. It makes one feel hurt and dismissed. This is an insidious form of emotional abuse that can leave the person fraught with self-doubt. 

I wrote this post a few months ago but I thought it deserved a place back up on the grid because it is relevant to this time of the year. I hope you find it helpful 🤍

What are some other ways you would respond to dismissing/ invalidating statements from others? 

Please use this information as a guide. Some of this information may not be relevant to your situation. Also, these conversations are best when done in relationships you want to maintain. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

What other reminders might you want to add for others who have difficult family relationships? 

One more thing I’d like to mention is that there is no such thing as the ‘perfect’ family. You are not alone in your experience. If you are spending time with family during the holidays, I encourage you to acknowledge the imperfections in your relationships, but don’t let that affect your energy and attitude. Allow yourself to also appreciate ‘the good’ - why you love them, and why you still care for them. Our brains naturally inflate negative situations in our memory as compared to positive experiences. Try to bring gratitude back into your attitude as you navigate difficult family dynamics. All the while, giving yourself grace if you lose patience every now and then. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Let’s take a moment to reflect on how to move forward in the new year.

Today I wanted to conceptualize how anxiety feels to someone internally vs. what you might see externally. 

Many of the things people with anxiety do might seem rude on the outside. But, if you can better understand their internal struggles, you might get a better sense of why they may seem hot and cold. 

We all experience anxiety to some extent. It is a normal human emotion. However, for some individuals, it can become debilitating. Please be understanding and compassionate with your loved ones who are affected with anxiety. 

If you are someone who regularly experiences anxiety, I’d encourage you to openly communicate what you feel with your loved-ones so they aren’t left wondering what might be causing you to withdraw, feel irritable, or seek constant reassurance. The statements in this post may help in this type of communication. 

Also, if you notice you do these things frequently, it’s important to work in reducing these behaviors so they have minimal impact on your day to day life and your relationships. You can do this through self-awareness, challenging your thoughts, mindfulness, and other healthy coping strategies for anxiety (including seeking help from a mental health professional).

Taking care of your mental health does not have to be expensive or complicated. Here are some simple, yet underrated habits that can optimize your psychological health in the best way possible (i.e. with the highest ROI - Return of Investment)

Which one of these do you already do? Which ones do you want to focus on more? 

The habits that I feel like I have successfully implemented into my routine are:
• good sleep because I can instantly feel I’m not cognitively and emotionally at my best when I have poor sleep
• journaling - I do this only when I’m distressed though or if I’m trying to make sense I’d a situation 
• movement - this really helps with the instant boost in my mood and just makes me feel accomplished and confident overall

Currently, I’m working on practicing mindfulness meditation every morning for 15 min and I’ve been improving a lot. Other habits I’d like to work on is hydrating and stepping out more to get sunlight.

Being productive does not mean using every waking moment of the day to get as much done as possible, as quickly as you can. This is what often leads to burnout. 

Our brain has a limited capacity for focused attention, especially when doing tasks that require more cognitive effort. Common estimates of attention span of healthy teenagers and adults range from 5 to 6 hours. However, it’s important to schedule in short breaks in between during this time of focused work. 

To optimize productivity, the key is to also consider the various other factors that increase focus, energy, and allow for efficiency, such as the ones listed here.

In this post, I wanted to explain what procrastination behaviors you may notice actually mean from a behavioral psychology standpoint. Procrastination is the intentional delay or avoidance of working on a task. 

Research shows that procrastination is largely a failure of self-regulation (an executive functioning skill). This includes inability to regulate negative feelings around doing the task or having poor impulse control. 

Procrastination may also be caused by having a lack or structure in your day (another executive functioning skill). For example, not planning and preparing for when to complete tasks ahead of time. 

So how do we stop procrastinating? Well, the first step is to identify the reason why you procrastinate. Awareness is essential. Which one of these reasons can you identify with? 

The next step is to create a system that keeps you focused and aligned to your future-self. One way we can do this is by using a planner to keep track of all tasks/goals and organize them in our days based on priority. 

If you are interested in using a planner and have a tablet, I encourage you to check out my Productivity Planner 2023 (link in bio). It is a digital planner compatible with most tablets. I designed it specifically to optimize productivity and reduce procrastination. For example it includes a mood journal so you can work through negative feelings around completing tasks. You can click the link in my bio to learn more.

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Sometimes in life, our biggest obstacle is our own self-sabotaging behavior. 

Self-sabotage is any action that gets in the. way of achieving our goals or maintaining our health. 

If we do not become aware of our self-sabotaging behaviors and keep neglecting them, we are at risk of losing trust in our own abilities which ultimately leads to a loss of self-confidence and self-worth.

The key is to understand how you are getting in your own way and start implementing small daily habits that allow you to change this maladaptive behavior. 

For example, if you notice your overthinking comes in the way of you getting started, try to push through this resistance by dedicating a small amount of time (15 or 30 min) to work on the task, despite the self-doubt and fear. Notice how you feel after. You might notice that the mental resistance has significantly subsided.

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

#selfsabotage #psychology #humanbehavior

Constantly criticizing the self can increase the release of cortisol in our body and keep us in a prolonged state of stress.

Instead of beating yourself up, I encourage you to view your experience with compassion and self love. Notice how this makes a difference in your attitude and overall state of mind. In fact, it might even lead to you navigate the situation through a more rational and calm approach, instead of a reactive and rushed one. 

You may not have control over what you are experiencing right now, but you do have control over how you decide to internally interpret your experience. Will you beat yourself up for it? Or will you try to support yourself through it? 

How do you try to maintain a positive and encouraging attitude?

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

#cognitivereframing #mindsetshift #mentalhealth #psychology

At this point, it seems any mental health challenge we face is ‘trauma’. Don’t get me wrong, I think it is incredible that people are opening up about their struggles and hardships more and more, but the the term ‘trauma’ is not the same as a stressful, overwhelming, or challenging experience. 

Overuse of this word gives permission to turn every event into a catastrophe, carving a path for self-victimization. Interpreting a stressful situation as ‘trauma’ may disempower us to address the stress or overwhelm we experience in an effective way. I also worry that it may strip away the severity of this condition, invalidating the person who truly lives with it.

This is not the first time a word used to identify a serious health condition has lost its meaning. One example that stands out is the word ‘retarded’. It was used to describe someone with a developmental delay in 1895. However, people began misusing it to insult someone. As a result, it fell out out use amongst healthcare professionals because of its evolution as degrading and hurtful. 

In my opinion, ‘trauma’ is evolving into any experience that leaves one with any negative emotional experience. Of course, language evolves and we can’t control that but I wonder how will we replace a word used to describe a deeply agonizing and painful experience that changes the person’s life to a point where they can’t live in peace. 

I posted this in my story yesterday and many of you suggested I add this on my feed so you can share it and so we can create a space for conversation. What do you think is the solution here? Is a solution even needed? 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

#whatistrauma #trauma #ptsd #traumaticexperience

For the people pleaser, it can feel exhausting spending so much time trying to be appreciated and liked by everyone around them. It may even lead to a shaky core sense of self. 

The first step in unlearning people-pleasing behaviors is recognizing *why* you are doing it. Becoming consciously aware of our intentions allows us to work on our maladaptive behaviours. 

Please note that people pleasing is not a clinical disorder. It is a behavioural pattern that often leads to strained relationships due to various reasons, such as resentment and burnout. 

This is my refined definition of a people pleaser. If you’ve been following me for a while, you’ll know I post on this topic often. Understanding this behavioural pattern has been very helpful for me because I had a lot of people pleasing tendencies myself. I’m still a work in progress but I know overtime, I have improved in my thinking, my beliefs, and as a result, my relationships. 

I’m wondering, if someone asks you to define a people pleaser, how would you define it? 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

The purpose of this post is to understand what people pleasing behavior looks like and how it can be easily confused with the belief that we are being ‘kind’ or ‘easy-going’ or 'understanding'. 

People pleasing is a learned behavior, also known as the 'fawn response' which is one of the four stress responses adopted by our nervous system. The other three being fight, flight, or freeze. The aim of the fawn response is to appease others and pacify the threat to maintain a sense of safety. 

This behavior is often learned in childhood, but can also be adopted later in life, such as in romantic relationships. In my next post, I will share more about why we people please and how to unlearn this response. 

Please note that people pleasing is not a clinical disorder. It is a behavioural pattern that often leads to strained relationships due to various reasons, such as resentment and burnout. 

I hope you find it helpful! Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

#peoplepleasing

There is power in understanding maladaptive behaviours and beliefs do not serve us anymore. Awareness allows us to consciously make an effort to unlearn these patterns and come out stronger on the other side.

People pleasing, or the fawn response, makes one susceptible to being mistreated and taken advantage of in relationships where boundaries are not respected and there is a lack of accountability. Moreover, it prevents one from seeking fulfilment from within because you many constantly rely on others to feel worthy or ‘good’.

This post is packed with information. If you identify as a people pleaser, I encourage you to take some time to reflect on the question prompts I’ve included in the post and identify small steps you can take to unlearn this pattern.

Why can’t we stop engaging in behaviors that we know are not good for us? Such as mindlessly scrolling on social media for longer than we want to, procrastinating on important tasks, repeatedly making unhealthy food choices, or choosing not to get up to exercise for 30 minutes?

Neuropsychologists consider this a self-regulation failure. Often, we are not aware of what we think and what we do before we act. Most of the time we live in autopilot – engaging in behaviors with little forethought. This can be due to various reasons, for example, the behavior was repeated enough times that it has turned into an automated habit or because you may be seeking instant gratification to feel better (i.e. less bored, distracted etc.). 

One way to manage this is by an exercise that I call ‘Noticing the Urge.’ Many variations of this have been implemented in psychotherapeutic interventions. This is how it goes – when you have the urge to engage in a behavior that you know is not serving you, notice your thought. For example, you may have the thought “I really want to sit here and watch tv instead of exercising.” 

Next, add the phrase “I am noticing I am having the urge!”. This small shift allows you to create a little bit of space between you and your thoughts. And it is in this space that you can choose to pause, think, and respond in a way that aligns with your goals. 

This works because it allows us to accept the thought as it is but also recognize that we do not have to act on every thought we have. There is so much power in that. In fact, this practice can also help build self-confidence because you began to trust yourself more. 

I hope you found this helpful. Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal 

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3062191/

Many of us skip working out when we aren’t feeling our best. However, this is the very time exercise has the greatest payoff. Exercise can helps us feel better and boost mood, leading to an increased likelihood that we will not relapse into old patterns or give up on our goals. 

Some ways regular exercise helps us feel better:
• increases serotonin production (leads to a meditative state and helps us feel good in the present moment) 
• helps release brain-derived neurotrophic factor (helps with neuroplasticity and neuronal growth) 
• provides a sense of accomplishment 
• reassured us that we can do hard things that are good for us even if they don’t feel great in the moment 
• helps reduce the impact of stress on the brain

So, if you had to prioritize one thing as you enter the new week, let it be moving your body in whatever way that works for you. 

What are some benefits you have observed on your mental health as a result of exercise? 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

#tb The need to control our environment is rooted in the fear of uncertainty. This tendency is exacerbated when we experience feelings of anxiety or hold ourselves to unrealistically high standards. Why? Because it is our brain's effort to create a sense of security and predictability. 

A persistent need to control every situation can negatively impact our mental health and relationships with others. In addition, it can keep us in a constant state of stress, releasing cortisol and impacting our overall health. 

For this reason, it is helpful to identify what things are in your control and allow yourself to let go of what you cannot control. Be intentional about your mindset and how you choose to spend your energy.

Frustration is a vague emotion and sometimes it can be difficult to understand why you are feeling this way. Frustration is often masked as anger, overwhelm, anxiety, or resentment - or any emotion that is difficult to sit with. 

However, always remember, your emotions are trying to teach you something. Maybe a boundary has been crossed, or a need is going unmet, or something feels inauthentic. Pretending these emotions do not exist or repressing them does not solve the problem. They will find a way to erupt out sooner or later. 

Sometimes feeling frustrated means we need rest and stop over-booking ourselves. Other times it might mean that you need to step away from an unhealthy relationship. Allow yourself to acknowledge what you are feeling. Pause and reflect on what it is telling you. 

I encourage you to save this post as a guided journaling resource when you feel frustrated. Here are the reflection prompts mentioned: 

• Do I have a need that is not being met?
• Has a boundary been crossed?
• Am I tolerating things I am not okay with? 
• Are my expectations realistic? 
• What can I do right now to make myself feel better? 
• How can I stand up for myself while being respectful and kind? 

Are there any other reflective questions you would add to this list? 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

What does having 'fun' look like for you? When was the last time when you actually had fun?

Fun (or play) is fuel for the soul. It allows us to break from our daily routine and experience carefree joy and recreation. 

So why don't we put greater importance on it? Play is a natural instinct for children. Our need for novelty and joy is not lost in adulthood, but somewhere along the way, we decided to make it low priority. 

A wealth of research has found the benefits of play. Dr. Stuart Brown (psychiatrist) has studied the power of play for decades. He defines play as "purposeless, all-consuming, and fun." I think of it as doing things simply because it makes you happy and brings you joy. 

Through his work, Dr. Brown found that play is important to foster a sense of purpose, promote resilience, reduce stress levels, and increase intelligence. More importantly, it helps improve our mental health. 

This weekend, I encourage you to schedule in time for play. I want to add that play or ‘fun’ is different from self-care. In self-care practices, we often do things that are not necessarily fun but are good for us. Play is simply doing things for the joy of it. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Psychological health often takes a hit after we experience significant life stressors and you may notice feeling all or most of the symptoms listed on the right side. 

This is when it becomes crucial to focus on our healing. Healing is the process of becoming sound and healthy again. It requires you to push yourself to do things that improve your mental health; however, they often go completely against what you might *feel* like doing. I think it is so important to understand this duality.

There is a term in DBT (dialectical behavioral therapy) known as Opposite Action which is defined as choosing to do exactly the opposite of what your emotion tells you to do. 

For example, when our mental health is poor, it can be VERY hard to push ourselves to exercise but it is one of best things we can do for our brain and body. So, even if you don't feel like doing it because you are tired and unmotivated, you must push through it. Do the Opposite Action. 

It can be helpful to start slow (baby steps) and slowly increase the time you spend prioritizing the things you see on the left side. Another tip is to not think too much about it. 

For example, if you plan to journal before bed, don't let your thoughts come in the way of the action. Right when you get to bed, pick up the journal before you lay down. Same thing with exercise - if you plan to do it in the morning, get up and start getting dressed for gym without letting your brain think for too long. With time, it will get easier. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

In grad school, I learned that the primitive brain is designed to help us survive. This means it will do anything in its power to protect us from potential threats. 

Unfortunately, the brain views ‘uncertainty’ as a threat and holds us back from doing things that are challenging, uncomfortable, or risky. But that is often how we learn, grow, and build self confidence. 

Another interesting thing the brain does is that it will keep us in situations that are ‘comfortable’ even if they are harming us or stalling our growth. Why? Because we have proven that we can survive in this situation even if it comes at a cost of our mental health and/or success. Since the brain cares most about survival, it will prefer the unfavourable familiar over the opportunistic unfamiliar. I ask that you read this part again and let this knowledge be your fuel to take action. 

Do it while you’re scared and embrace the discomfort you feel. Reappraise this feeling as courage for stepping out into the opportunistic unfamiliar. 

Note: If you are someone who has heightened anxiety (clinical), moving through uncertainty is likely more debilitating for you and it might be tough to overcome on your own. I’d suggest seeking out professional help if that is the case, and in the meantime, take baby steps to move forward with compassion. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Rumination is a natural response to stress. When we are dealing with hard things, our brain can find it hard to separate that distress from what we are doing in the present. It leads to the mind to wander away from what is in front of you. 

You can imagine what this does to our attention span and ability to think. And, science backs this up. Research shows that constant rumination leads to decreased activity in the prefrontal cortex, the area of the brain involved in executive functions (making sound decisions, solving problems, self-regulating, etc.)

When I get into a cycle of rumination, I also notice that I lose track of time which results in me feeling like I have no control over my days. Not being able to do things or think the way I usually do results in further self-criticism. During this time, the strategy that helps me most is mindfulness practice. I force myself to notice the sensations in my body, for example my hands slightly tingling without me moving them and how my back feels leaning against the couch. I also notice what is around me and try to appreciate that exact moment in time. This helps me to focus my thoughts on the present and can cultivate gratitude in my mind. 

What is a strategy that helps you most with rumination? I'd love if you share your experience so other people who might be going through this thought pattern can read suggestions and try out one that resonates with them. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Alexithymia: a psychological condition that makes it hard for one to recognize and identify their emotions. It is unclear why this condition develops, however, genetics, trauma, depression, and neurodivergence are all possible factors. 

I’ve received a few messages about difficulties with identifying feelings and understanding what the emotion might be teaching you. So today, I wanted to share with you an older post of mine that explains the meaning behind some difficult (unpleasant) and positive emotions. 

Understanding and working through our emotions increases emotional intelligence. It allows us to process what we are feeling and respond respectfully instead of reacting impulsively. A build-up of uncomfortable emotions can cause dysregulation in our nervous system. Whereas, acknowledgment of positive emotions can lead to feelings of joy and gratitude. 

An important first step to working through our emotions is naming/recognizing them. A mood journal can help or you might simply want to self-reflect while doing something relaxing, such as walking in nature or sitting in a quiet space. This may not be easy because many of us struggle with identifying what we are feeling (approximately 10% of people in the US have Alexithymia).

To work through your emotions, try to take a moment to sit with what you are feeling and name the emotion(s) you feel. Once you do this, use this post as a guide to understand the underlying meaning of the emotion. This might help you better address your situation and take action accordingly. Please note that each emotion can have more than one underlying meaning. I tried to share the most common explanation.

I encourage you to save this post and use it as a resource for when you want to journal or work through your emotions. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

#emotionregulation #emotionalintelligence

When you’re feeling insecure or not good enough, it can be helpful to say encouraging statements to yourself that can help you regain your confidence and self-esteem. Here are some examples of statements (including 3 that i mention in this reel) that you can say to yourself when you feel insecure:

“I am enough just as I am.”
“My insecurity is a reflection of my fears, not my ability.”
“I am capable of achieving my goals.”
“I am not perfect and that is okay with me.”
“I am proud of my accomplishments so far.”
“I have overcome challenges in the past and can do it again.”
“I am strong and resilient.”
“I am confident in myself and my abilities.”
“I am deserving of happiness and success.”

Remember, everyone experiences feelings of insecurity from time to time, and it’s okay to feel vulnerable. Saying positive statements to yourself can help you shift your mindset and focus on your strengths and capabilities, rather than your perceived weaknesses. 

Why is this important? Studies have also shown that self-compassion, which involves treating ourselves with kindness, understanding, and support, can have positive effects on the brain and overall well-being. It can activate the brain’s reward system, which triggers the release of feel-good hormones such as oxytocin and endorphins. This can promote feelings of happiness and relaxation. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

The main underlying concept of CBT is that our feelings and behaviours are largely influenced by how we interpret the situation. We respond to our circumstances based on how we perceive them. However, sometimes our perception does not match our reality (due to our beliefs, fears, and insecurities) and leads to 'negative' thoughts that are unhelpful and not true. 

The negative thought shown on the left is an example of a cognitive distortion. We may be susceptible to getting caught in this unhelpful pattern of thinking if we are unaware of how our brain can trick us. This is why it is important to recognize when our thoughts are unhelpful and question them until this way of self-regulating becomes automatic for us.

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Working yourself into a state of constant stress and anxiety is not a badge of honor - it's a recipe for burnout. I encourage you to let go of the pressure and sense of urgency to complete tasks and meet deadlines. Trust that balance leads to better results."

According to a 2021 study, employees who experienced high levels of pressure to meet work demands also reported lower levels of productivity and performance. Another study published in the Journal of Applied Psychology found that employees who felt pressured to work long hours and respond to work-related communication outside of normal work hours were more likely to experience negative health outcomes, such as burnout and emotional exhaustion. These findings suggest that while it may seem counterintuitive, prioritizing our well-being and finding balance in our work and personal lives can actually lead to better performance and productivity.

Cognitive reappraisal is a cognitive-behavioral technique that involves reevaluating and reframing negative thoughts or situations in a more positive or constructive way. It can be a helpful tool for reducing productivity anxiety because it addresses the negative thoughts and beliefs that can contribute to anxiety and stress.

When we experience productivity anxiety, we may have negative thoughts such as "I'm not doing enough" or "I'll never be able to finish everything on time." These thoughts can lead to feelings of overwhelm and self-doubt, which can further impact our productivity and performance. By using cognitive reappraisal, we can challenge these negative thoughts and replace them with more positive and realistic ones.

Our thoughts influence the way we feel. A type of meditation is being mindful of what we are thinking. It allows us to step back and recognize when we have fallen into a "thinking trap" often called a cognitive distortion. 

We are able to change the way we feel and behave by identifying our negative thoughts and changing the meaning we give them. This is the basic concept behind cognitive behavioral therapy. 

In this post are cognitive distortions that tend to exacerbate anxiety. If you are feeling anxious, I encourage you to try to identify the thought associated with this feeling, and determine whether it fits into one of these thinking traps. 

Then I encourage you to come up with an alternative thought that considers other explanations/ outcomes. 

Which one of these cognitive distortions do you find yourself engaging in most?

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Stop for a second. Pause. Notice what you feel.

Name this feeling. Many of us feel more than one emotion at a time, so don’t hesitate to identify multiple emotions you might be feeling. Also, something to note is usually a strong emotion that hides behind others is fear.

Accept the emotion. Instead of shaming or criticizing yourself for being emotional, recognize that what you are feeling is valid and human. Offer self-compassion.

Make a choice about how to respond. It is difficult to control our emotions as they come up but we can control how we respond to this emotion. Once we understand this, it can be a powerful way to minimize unpleasant emotions. 

The steps above are an exercise to regulate some common emotions that may make us uncomfortable or uneasy in the moment. They may not work for everyone (as intensity and individual circumstances matter), but I encourage you to try practicing them yourself and see how you feel. I hope this helps!

There is a scientific basis for the idea of doing the hardest thing first, which is based on the concept of willpower and decision fatigue.

Willpower is a limited resource that can be depleted throughout the day as we make decisions and exert self-control. This means that the more decisions we make, the less willpower we have left to make additional decisions later in the day. When we save the hardest task for later in the day, we may be more likely to procrastinate or make decisions that require less willpower.

Research has also shown that our ability to make good decisions decreases as the day goes on. This is known as decision fatigue and can lead to poor choices or indecision. By tackling the hardest task first, we can avoid decision fatigue and ensure that we have enough mental energy to make good decisions throughout the day.

In terms of productivity peaks, it is true that not everyone is a morning person and may not feel their sharpest early in the day. However, research has shown that the morning is typically the time when we have the most willpower and decision-making ability due to increased cortisol and dopamine levels. This means that even if we don’t feel our best, we may still be better equipped to tackle the hardest task first in the morning. 

That being said, it’s important to find a time that works best for you personally. If you find that you are more productive and focused in the afternoon or evening, it may be better for you to tackle the hardest task then. Ultimately, the key is to be aware of your own productivity patterns and to use that knowledge to structure your day in a way that maximizes your output.

Take care of your mind and body.

It is easier to say “I’m fine” and pretend to be okay. There are many reasons why we might do this:

1. We hold back from the emotion and refuse to acknowledge how we feel. This is especially true if we grew up in an environment where feelings were not talked about or we were punished for expressing our feelings

2. We want to avoid conflict. Sharing how we feel may upset or anger the other person and that can be uncomfortable or scary. 

3. We are used to being avoidant and deal with our feelings on our own. This is a learned attachment style that stems from a childhood where our needs were neglected or ignored. This results in the child learning that they should not ask for anything. 

4. Maybe we actually are not mad anymore. Choosing our battles and letting go of small things promotes peace of mind. In that case, it might be best to let the person clearly know you did not like what they did but want to move on (see example 4 in the post)

Acknowledging your anger and having difficult conversations to resolve the situation can be powerful in strengthening relationships and ensuring unhealthy patterns are not repeated. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Let’s talk about the silent treatment, also known as stonewalling. 

People may resort to using the silent treatment as a way to express their anger, frustration, or disappointment towards someone else. Here are some reasons why people may use the silent treatment:

Communication issues: People who have difficulty expressing their emotions or communicating their needs may use the silent treatment as a way to avoid confrontation or difficult conversations. They may feel that it is easier to withdraw and shut down rather than engage in a potentially challenging conversation.

Passive aggression: The silent treatment can also be a form of passive aggression. People who are angry or upset may use the silent treatment as a way to punish or manipulate the other person without actually communicating what is bothering them.

Power dynamics: In some cases, the silent treatment may be used as a way to assert power or control over another person. By withholding communication or attention, the person using the silent treatment may be trying to assert their dominance or make the other person feel powerless.

Emotional regulation: Some people may use the silent treatment as a way to regulate their own emotions. They may feel overwhelmed or upset and need time to calm down and process their feelings before they can communicate effectively.

It's important to note that while the silent treatment may be a common way of expressing anger or frustration in some relationships, it can be harmful and hurtful to the other person. Communication is a key component of healthy relationships, and avoiding communication through the silent treatment can lead to misunderstandings, conflict, and damage to the relationship.

Take care is your mind and body. 
Love, Nawal ♥️

#stonewalling #relationships #silenttreatment

When it comes to communication, silence can have different meanings. In my last post, there were interesting discussions on this topic; however, there was some confusion about the difference between the ‘silent treatment’ and taking a pause. These are two distinct practices with diverse intentions. 

With the silent treatment, the aim is to control and punish others by giving them the cold shoulder. It fosters isolation and manipulation, causing lasting harm to relationships. 

On the other hand, taking a pause is a healthy communication strategy. It allows for introspection, gathering thoughts, and maintaining composure during intense discussions. It fosters understanding, empathy, and promotes constructive dialogue. 

It’s important to note that there are nuances to this depending on the type of relationship and what both people are okay or not okay with. 

Remember, the key difference between the two lies in intent and duration. While silent treatment inflicts pain and cuts off communication, a temporary pause encourages thoughtful responses and prevents conflicts from escalating. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Different activities target the regulation of specific negative emotions:

1. If you are sad, engaging in activities you find pleasurable can help distract your mind from negative thoughts and stimulate the release of endorphins, which are natural mood-boosting chemicals. Being outdoors, especially in nature, can also have a calming effect on your mind and emotions.

2. If you are feeling stressed, practicing deep breathing for 5 minutes can help alleviate your stress response. Deep breathing exercises activate the body’s relaxation response, triggering a physiological shift from the “fight-or-flight” response to a more relaxed state. 

3. Breaking tasks into smaller, more achievable steps allows you to focus on one manageable task at a time, reducing the feeling of being overwhelmed. This approach can provide a sense of accomplishment as you complete each step, gradually building momentum and confidence.

4. If you are feeling anxious, challenging your thoughts with cognitive reframing can be effective. Anxiety often stems from irrational or negative thinking patterns that exaggerate potential threats or outcomes. Cognitive reframing involves identifying and questioning these anxious thoughts, then replacing them with more realistic ones. 

5. If you are feeling irritable, engaging in exercise for at least 30 minutes can help dissipate pent-up energy and improve your mood. Physical activity releases endorphins and stimulates the production of dopamine and serotonin, which are neurotransmitters associated with feelings of happiness and well-being.

It’s important to note that these activities can be helpful for many people, but individual experiences may vary. It’s always advisable to seek professional help if you consistently struggle with regulating your emotions or if they significantly interfere with your daily life.

Take care is your mind and body. 
Love, Nawal ♥️

When we experience loss, healing becomes an essential process. In our lifetime, we can experience different types of losses, such as loss of a loved-one, loss of a relationship (i.e., divorce), loss of one's health, loss of one's stability or job, loss of dreams and aspirations, etc.

In this post are a few common signs that you are in the process of healing from loss. 

Not too long ago, I experienced a significant loss that forced me into healing after weeks of grief. I did not realize how incredibly challenging the healing process can be, but putting in intentional effort to move forward and heal is worth it for your future-self.

Here are a few things that I noticed made the process of healing from loss difficult:

1. Healing from loss is not a linear process with a set timeline. It can be prolonged, with periods of progress followed by setbacks. The unpredictability can be frustrating and disheartening, making it challenging to see progress. Learn to embrace the ups and downs of this process without judgment. 

2. Grief can evoke intense emotions, including sadness, anger, guilt, and confusion. Navigating and processing these emotions can be overwhelming and demanding, and it requires us to confront our pain and vulnerabilities. This is not easy to do when you are already feeling symptoms of depression, so giving yourself grace during this time is crucial. 

3. Societal expectations often place pressure on us to "move on" quickly or suppress our grief. This can create added stress and feelings of isolation, making it harder to heal authentically and at one's own pace. When this happens, remind yourself that your health is more of a priority than what people expect of you. 

Remember, healing is a unique process, and it may not always follow a linear path. Be patient with yourself, allow yourself to grieve, and trust that with time, support, and self-care, you can find your own path to healing.

For Mental Health Awareness month, I teamed up with @optionb to bring awareness about the healing process after loss and reclaiming strength to move forward. We hope you found this post helpful!

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Pretending to be ‘okay’ when you are not can be incredibly challenging and exhausting. This happens because when you’re struggling with intense emotions or mental distress, it requires a significant amount of emotional and cognitive energy to mask those feelings and maintain a facade of being okay. Constantly suppressing or hiding emotions takes a toll on your psychological well-being, leading to increased stress and fatigue.

In addition, When there is a stark contrast between your inner emotional state and the outward appearance you portray, it creates a state of emotional incongruence. This dissonance between what you feel and how you present yourself can be mentally taxing, as it requires continuous effort to manage conflicting emotions and maintain a consistent external image.

However, it is important to recognize that constantly pretending to be okay is not a sustainable long-term solution. Prolonged states of distress or emotional suppression can affect the brain’s neurochemical balance. For instance, chronic stress associated with pretending to be okay can disrupt the release of neurotransmitters like serotonin and dopamine, which are crucial for regulating mood and motivation. 

This is why it is so necessary to give yourself grace during this time, slow down and prioritize self-care, allow yourself the space to process and express your true emotions, and seek support from loved ones and/or professionals.

How do you try to slow down when you’re going through a tough time?

We may not realize when we have weak boundaries if we grew up in an environment where boundaries were rarely respected. It may be difficult for us to identify when we start to feel small, neglected, or resentful because we may have become desensitized to these experiences. 

Repeated experiences in our lives start to feel normal to us even when they are not good for us. As children, if we were not given healthy permission to say no, then we may have difficulty to be okay with saying no in adulthood. If we never learned to take up space, then we may be later challenged to express our opinions and thoughts in a room full of people. If there was no room to talk about our emotions growing up, then it might be hard for us to name what we are feeling and acknowledge it. 

The good news is that we all have the power to change. Our brains create new patterns and behaviors through neuroplasticity. It takes more work on our end initially, but with consistent practice, these behaviors become automatic to us. 

However, the first step is understanding ourselves better. How were your boundaries violated and neglected in the past? How does that impact your ability to set boundaries for yourself? 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

As a clinical psychologist and scientist, I have always been fascinated by the power of attachment in shaping our lives. After learning that attachment styles form in early childhood but can affect how we handle our relationships as we grow, I decided to dedicate my life to conducting research on improving attachment security, helping people navigate their relationships with more confidence.  
People who are securely attached generally have an easier time creating and maintaining healthy relationships. They feel comfortable with emotional closeness, independence, and trust.  Due to more inconsistent early childhood experiences, those who are anxiously attached crave emotional closeness but also fear abandonment. They may seek constant reassurance from their partners, which can create ups and downs in their relationships.  People with avoidant attachment tendencies have learned to be more independent and may have difficulty with emotional intimacy. They prefer to keep their distance and may struggle to express their emotions.
 Those with more disorganized attachment tendencies (also called fearful avoidant attachment) may have experienced traumatic, abusive, or inconsistent relationships. This unpredictability can make it difficult to consistently trust and open up.
 
It's important to note that attachment styles are not fixed and can be influenced by personal growth, therapy, and supportive relationships. Developing self-awareness and understanding one's attachment style can provide insights into relationship patterns and help you work towards more secure and fulfilling connections.

Healing anxious attachment tendencies is possible in many ways. One of these ways is by learning to reflect and detach from negative core beliefs (e.g., I will always be abandoned).

Gaining distance from these beliefs gives us the freedom to mindfully choose how we want to show up in our relationships instead of making decisions that are guided by our unconscious wounds.

My current research at Stanford University focuses on developing and testing this theoretical model (slide 2), which shows how attachment anxiety is maintained across time (Manvelian et al., in preparation).

My hope is that this model can create a map for you, a guide, helping you understand how this cycle operates within you and giving you the power to break it.

Fearful avoidant attachment (aka disorganized attachment) occurs when love becomes associated with fear. 

For example, if growing up, our parent acted warm and loving on some days but aggressive and abusive on others, our nervous systems cannot rest around them. As a result of this unpredictability, we are left confused about what to expect, always waiting for love to turn into frightening behavior.

Healing fearful avoidant attachment can feel difficult but it’s possible. 

Gaining distance from the beliefs that keep you stuck and allowing yourself to learn into closeness (even when it’s scary!) can help you create more secure patterns of attachment over time.

My current research at Stanford University focuses on developing and testing this theoretical model (slide 2), which shows how fearful avoidant attachment is maintained across time (Manvelian et al., in preparation).

My hope is that this model can create a map for you, a guide, helping you understand how this cycle operates within you and giving you the power to break it.

Dismissive avoidant attachment can develop if close others were emotionally unavailable or rejecting, forcing us to suppress our emotions and natural attachment needs. In these circumstances, relying on others becomes associated with weakness and hyper-independence is rewarded.

Healing these patterns can be difficult, but it’s possible. We must challenge the thoughts that keep us stuck and find the courage to open back up to connection, giving us the love and compassion we deserve.

Anxiety can dramatically affect our ability to function well at home, work, or social situations. While the causes of anxiety are varied, it’s helpful to identify potential triggers, practice mindfulness, and use stress-relief techniques to try to overcome them. It is important to note that there are physical and emotional symptoms of anxiety.

Physical Symptoms of Anxiety Look Like: 
• Tight chest
• Increased heart rate
• Nausea, upset stomach
• Sweating
• Difficulty concentrating

Emotional Symptoms of Anxiety Look Like:
• Feeling Overwhelmed About the Future
• Fixating on the worst case scenario
• Overthinking 
• Feeling Irritable/ On Edge
• Being Restless

When we are aware of these symptoms, we can use the strategies above to minimize feelings of anxiety. If you feel like feelings of anxiety are happening for more extended periods, and interferes with day-to-day living, I highly recommend to seek help from a professional.

Happiness isn’t just about how much you achieve. While those things may make us feel good temporarily, true happiness comes from finding joy in the journey and appreciating what we have right now. 

For example, let’s say you think, “I’ll be happy when I lose 15 pounds.” Losing weight can be a healthy goal, but it’s important to find happiness in taking care of your body and feeling good about yourself, regardless of the number on the scale. Finding joy in being active, eating nutritious food, and appreciating the progress you make along the way can bring lasting happiness.

Similarly, if you think, “I’ll be happy when I get that promotion,” it’s important to remember that happiness shouldn’t solely rely on external achievements. While a promotion may bring some happiness, true fulfillment comes from enjoying the work you do, building positive relationships with colleagues, and feeling proud of your accomplishments, even if they’re not recognized with a title or position.

So instead of putting all our happiness on reaching specific goals, it’s better to focus on finding joy in the small things, like spending time with loved ones, pursuing hobbies we enjoy, or doing things that make us laugh and feel good. By appreciating the present and finding happiness in everyday moments, we can experience true and lasting happiness.

What is one thing you will do today that brings you joy?

Imagine you're playing a game, and you have two options: to focus on things you can control or worry about things you can't control. Which one do you think will make you feel stronger and more in charge?

When you focus on what you can control, like your own actions, decisions, and efforts, it's like having a superpower. You can choose to do things that make a difference in your life. For example, if you have a test coming up, you can study hard and be prepared. By doing that, you increase your chances of doing well.

On the other hand, there are things that you simply can't control. Like the weather, other people's actions, or what will happen in the future. It's like trying to control the wind or make someone else do what you want. It's frustrating and often impossible.

So, when you let go of things you can't control, it's like putting down a heavy backpack that's dragging you down. Instead of wasting your energy and getting upset about things you can't change, you can use that energy to focus on things you can control and make a positive impact in your own life.

Remember, focusing on what you can control gives you power and makes you feel strong. Letting go of what you can't control helps you feel lighter and more at peace. So, it's important to ask yourself: "Can I control this?" If the answer is no, it's better to let go and focus on what you can control.

Exercise: Make a list of things in your life that are stressing you out and categorize them into ‘I can control’ and ‘I cannot control’. Reflect on whether you have been trying to change things that are out of your control and how that has affected you.

A cognitive distortion that we commonly experience is the 'should' statement. It is a thought that creates rigid rules about how you should be doing something. This cognitive distortion also affects your thoughts about other people - how they ought to be or must do things. 

When I first learned about 'should' statements as a cognitive distortion, I was a little confused. We do have obligations and there are things we ‘should’ be doing to accomplish a specific goal. But …. we can get into trouble when our 'should' thoughts lead us to feel guilty and discouraged. If these statements are targeted toward others, they can lead to resentments that may not be warranted. 

To understand whether your 'should' statement is rational and not a false sense of obligation, ask yourself "Why is this important?". When you can provide a reason that is rational and not underlying fear or guilt, then it is a relevant thought. 

Unhelpful 'should' statements can make us inflexible in our decisions and may leave us feeling stuck in our situation. 

What are your thoughts on the 'should' statements being a thinking error?

What does having 'fun' look like for you? When was the last time when you actually had fun?

Fun (or play) is fuel for the soul. It allows us to break from our daily routine and experience carefree joy and recreation. 

So why don't we put greater importance on it? Play is a natural instinct for children. Our need for novelty and joy is not lost in adulthood, but somewhere along the way, we decided to make it low priority. 

A wealth of research has found the benefits of play. Dr. Stuart Brown (psychiatrist) has studied the power of play for decades. He defines play as "purposeless, all-consuming, and fun." 

Through his work, he found that play is important to foster a sense of purpose, promote resilience, reduce stress levels, and increase intelligence. More importantly, it helps improve our mental health. 

This week, I encourage you to schedule in time for play. I want to add that play or ‘fun’ is different from self-care. In self-care practices, sometimes we do things that are not necessarily fun but are good for us. Play is simply doing things for the joy of it.

Which one of these practices do you want to incorporate more of in your life? Please note that some of these practices have multiple benefits. I’m sharing some of the most prominent ones. 

Meditation, can improve focus and attention by enhancing the brain’s prefrontal cortex, responsible for executive functions. For beginners, starting with 5-10 minutes of daily meditation and gradually increasing the duration is beneficial.

Deep breathing activates the parasympathetic nervous system, which promotes relaxation and counters the body’s stress response. Engaging in deep breathing for a few minutes several times a day can be beneficial in managing stress and promoting a sense of calm.

Mindfulness practices reduce activity in the amygdala, the brain’s fear center. Regular mindfulness practice of 20-30 minutes per day can be helpful in reducing anxiety symptoms.

Expressing gratitude rewires the brain to focus on positive aspects of life, leading to improved mood and overall well-being. Engaging in a daily gratitude journal or reflection can be beneficial for mood enhancement.

Visualization activates the brain’s reward circuitry similarly to experiencing the actual reward. It increases dopamine release and strengthens neural connections related to motivation and goal pursuit. Take a few minutes each day to visualize successful outcomes of your goals.

Physical exercise stimulate the release of neurotrophic factors, which promote brain plasticity and improve cognitive function. Exercise enhances memory, attention, and executive functions. The recommended amount of exercise for cognitive benefits is around 150 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise per week, combined with strength training 2-3 times per week.

Sleep is crucial for brain restoration. Adequate nutrition provides the necessary nutrients for brain function and energy production. Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep and maintain a balanced diet with natural, whole foods. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal♥️

Anxiety paralysis refers to a state of intense anxiety (and sometimes panic), leading to a complete or partial inability to take action or make decisions. 

During anxiety paralysis, you may feel emotionally or mentally stuck, immobilized, or unable to cope with the situation you are facing.

Anxiety is a natural and common human emotion, and everyone experiences anxiety to some degree at various points in life. In situations of extreme stress, pressure, or fear, individuals without a clinical anxiety disorder can also experience anxiety-induced paralysis.

Anxiety paralysis is essentially a manifestation of the body's "fight-or-flight" response, which is an innate survival mechanism. When faced with a perceived threat or overwhelming situation, the body's sympathetic nervous system is activated, triggering various physical and psychological responses, including increased heart rate, rapid breathing, and a surge of stress hormones like cortisol.

In some cases, this heightened state of arousal can lead to a "freeze" response, where an individual may feel mentally or physically stuck, unable to take action or make decisions. 

While anxiety paralysis is a common experience, it's important to differentiate between occasional feelings of anxiety and clinically diagnosed anxiety disorders. Clinical anxiety disorders are characterized by persistent and excessive anxiety that significantly interferes with daily functioning and well-being. If you or someone you know experiences this, seeking support from mental health professionals can be beneficial in managing anxiety and developing coping strategies to navigate overwhelming situations more effectively.

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Anxiety occurs when the brain senses a potential threat that may or may not be immediately present. For example, flight anxiety or health anxiety are responses to an immediate potential threat. 

But sometimes, the trigger for anxiety can be uncertain, vague, or not as easily identifiable as the immediate threat that triggers fear. It can feel overwhelming because you're not sure exactly what's causing it. This type of anxiety is often associated with an overactive amygdala, the part of the brain responsible for detecting threats and triggering the fear response. This post by @health_anxiety beautifully captures this type of anxiety.

In situations where the threat is unclear or not easily identifiable, the amygdala can become hypersensitive, leading to a heightened state of anxiety.During this time, the amygdala is constantly scanning the environment and your thoughts for any potential signs of danger, even if there isn't an immediate threat. This constant scanning can keep you in a state of hyperarousal, with your body on high alert for potential dangers that may not even exist.

To combat anxiety when you're unsure about its cause, these tips can be helpful:

Practice mindfulness techniques to stay present in the moment. Ground yourself by focusing on your senses—what you see, hear, feel, taste, and smell right now. This can help divert your attention from vague worries and bring you back to the present reality.

Engage in deep breathing exercises to activate the relaxation response in your brain. Take slow, deep breaths, counting to four as you inhale, holding for four counts, and then exhaling for four counts. This calms your nervous system and reduces anxiety.

Identify any anxious thoughts that are floating in your mind and challenge their validity. Ask yourself if there's any concrete evidence to support these thoughts or if you're catastrophizing. Remind yourself that it's okay not to have all the answers right now.

Be patient with yourself, and if anxiety persists and interferes with your daily life, consider seeking professional help.

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

Our thoughts are not always true. Yet, they almost always influence how we feel in the moment and ultimately respond. 

Being mindful of how our thoughts are affecting us allows us to step back and recognize when we have fallen into a "thinking trap" often called a cognitive distortion. 

Cognitive distortions are unhelpful thoughts that come up when we perceive a situation negatively without consideration of alternative and more realistic explanations. Being in this state of mind can exacerbate symptoms of anxiety and stress. 

Which one of these cognitive distortions do you find yourself engaging in most? 

If you are feeling anxious, try to write down the thoughts and beliefs that are occupying your mind right now. Do any of them fit into the cognitive distortions mentioned in this post? Next, ask yourself, "How do I know this thought is true?" And "How do I know this thought is not true?" Challenge the validity of your thought and consider other explanations and outcomes. Notice how you feel after. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

When we approach threat, a defensive response is elicited inside us. Our response depends on how we *perceive* the threat. Our brain is wired to protect us against threats. This is beneficial in some situations, but it can also be destructive, especially if it is our ego we are trying so hard to protect. 

Early on in life, we learn ways to deflect threats by observing our parents or siblings. These defenses felt protective and safe to us as a child; however, they serve us little to no benefit in adulthood. When we *feel* threatened by something someone says or does, we may engage in the behaviors I mention in this post.

It is hard to recognize of we are being defensive in the moment. We are often so occupied with protecting ourselves that we don’t realize how our behavior may be impacting others. This can have a negative effect on our relationship with others and ourselves.

Next time you feel the need to engage in defensive behavior, I urge you to become consciously aware of it. Try to control the impulse to respond and identify the threat you are perceiving. Ask yourself whether the threat is real. If it is not, prevent yourself from exacerbating the situation by allowing yourself time to calm down. If it is, learn to communicate in a manner that is effective and positive to prevent further threat. 

What helps you overcome your defensive behavior?

The purpose of this post is to understand what people pleasing behavior looks like day-to-day. In my next post, I will share more about why we people please and how to unlearn this response.

Our brains are pretty complex, and they can play tricks on us. Neuroscientific studies have shown that emotions can significantly influence our thought processes. When we are in a negative emotional state or not in the best headspace, our brain may become more attuned to negative information and interpret neutral or ambiguous situations in a negative light. This emotional bias can distort our thinking and lead to inaccurate conclusions.

Here are a couple of questions you can ask yourself to challenge your thoughts when you’re feeling off:

1.	Is this thought based on facts or is it just an assumption?
Think of this like being a detective. Try to figure out if your thought is backed up by real evidence or if it’s more like a guess. Sometimes, we jump to conclusions without having all the facts, and that’s where we can get tripped up.

2.	What is an alternative thought that can explain why I am thinking this way or feeling this way?
Imagine you’re looking at a situation from a different angle. What other explanations could there be for why you’re thinking or feeling this way? This can help you see that there might be more than one way to interpret things.

To work through your thoughts, it may help to answer the above questions through journaling - it’s like taking a step back and looking at your thoughtss from a distance. It can make things clearer and help you spot patterns in your thinking.

So, in a nutshell, remember that your thoughts aren’t always the ultimate truth. They can be deceiving, especially when you’re not feeling your best. But with a bit of detective work and some journaling, you can start to see things more clearly and find better ways to cope with what’s bothering you. 

Take care of your mind and body ♥️
Love, Nawal

Striving for your aspirations can be challenging. It may require effort, determination, and overcoming obstacles. But living a life that lacks passion and fulfillment is even more challenging. It can lead to a sense of dissatisfaction and regret.

Ending a relationship, particularly when it’s unhappy, is emotionally and mentally demanding. It involves making a difficult decision and facing uncertainty about the future. However, staying in such a relationship can be even more psychologically and emotionally taxing. It can lead to prolonged distress and unhappiness.

Establishing and maintaining healthy boundaries in relationships can be challenging, as it may involve assertiveness and potential conflict, but resenting and feeling overwhelmed due to a lack of boundaries can be far more psychologically taxing.

Reaching out for help, whether for mental health or life challenges, can be difficult due to stigma or pride. But trying to handle all problems and stressors without support can lead to burnout, anxiety, and poor mental health.

Life is filled with tough challenges, but some choices can lead to a more fulfilling and psychologically healthy life. If have the option/ability to choose your hard, I encourage you to evaluate the long term benefits of your decision in terms of psychological well being.

One of the most affordable and effective form of self-care is getting enough sleep. Our body and brain needs sleep to refuel. It allows us to stay focused, think clearly, be more productive, and feel more positive throughout the day.

Sleep is a lot more important than we think. Sleep deprivation negatively affects the prefrontal cortex, which impacts emotions, brain performance, and attention. A slowing down of these cognitive functions can affect daily tasks like work efficiency, conversational listening, or even watching the news (Miller et al., 2014). Not getting enough sleep can also increase the risk of anxiety, mental health problems and health issues. 

Some areas of functioning affected due to poor sleep quality are:
- thought processing
- forgetfulness
- job performance 
- anger/irritability
- overall life satisfaction

So if you aren't getting enough sleep, here is your gentle reminder to make the necessary changes in your routine to prioritize it. 

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️
