Being confident in ourselves makes us more resilient in facing life's challenges. It allows us to believe that we can do hard things and face setbacks without being crippled by self-doubt. It helps us feel worthy and gives us strength. 

When it comes to combating self-rejection, self-confidence acts as a powerful antidote. When we're confident, we're less likely to entertain negative self-perceptions or be overly concerned about external validation. Instead, we develop a healthier relationship with ourselves, understanding that our worth isn't determined by others' opinions. This shift allows us to accept ourselves more fully and reduces the tendency to reject aspects of ourselves preemptively.

Improving self-confidence involves nurturing a positive self-image, acknowledging accomplishments, and embracing self-compassion. It also means keeping promises we make to ourselves, which means honoring commitments and goals we set for our own well-being and growth. It involves treating our personal commitments with the same importance and respect that we would give to promises made to others. For instance, it could involve commitments related to self-care routines, personal development goals, or maintaining healthy habits.

As self-confidence grows, the grip of self-rejection weakens. It's like building a shield against the negative thoughts that lead to self-rejection, fostering a more resilient and positive self-perception.

When we’re not confident in ourselves, we often end up living by what other people think is right rather than what we truly believe. It happens because we feel good when others approve of us. But when we prioritize their opinions over our own, we kind of forget what we actually stand for.

“Living Your Best Life” a masterguide on Shortform  discusses about how this need for approval starts early in life. We figure out that fitting into what others want brings comfort and happiness. But here’s the thing: if we let this need for approval take over, it leads to feeling unhappy and unsatisfied for three main reasons:

Firstly, we might end up chasing goals that don’t really fulfill us. 

Second, we might feel like something’s missing but believe we can’t change it. 

And lastly, by constantly seeking validation, we might hide our true feelings, leading to reactions we’re not proud of.

These points really hit home about why it’s crucial to not let other people’s opinions dictate everything about us. Of course, it’s about finding a balance and owning up to our mistakes, but at the end of the day, it’s vital to stay true to ourselves.

Research has found that procrastination is not a time-management issue but more of a self-regulation problem.

We procrastinate when we are unable to manage negative feelings around a task (such as boredom, anxiety, insecurity, frustration, resentment, and self-doubt). This is especially true when we have “task aversion”. Maybe the task is too boring or maybe it is really complex and that stresses you out. You want to avoid negative feelings when you think about the task, so you might open up Pinterest or go on a YouTube spiral instead. 

To make things worse, when we are under distress, the rational part of the brain (i.e. the prefrontal cortex) shuts down and the amygdala (the part of the brain that moderates our fear response) perceives the task as a genuine threat to our self-esteem or our mental health. This is known as the amygdala hijack and it’s a time when we are most prone to putting off the task because our brains are more concerned about removing the threat in the present moment (leading to avoidance behaviours). 

The 10 minute rule is a helpful way to minimize procrastination and take action before our emotions and brain talk us out of doing it.

Why can’t we stop engaging in behaviors that we know are not good for us? Such as mindlessly scrolling on social media for longer than we want to, procrastinating on important tasks, repeatedly making unhealthy food choices, or choosing not to get up to exercise for 30 minutes?

Neuropsychologists consider this a self-regulation failure. Often, we are not aware of what we think and what we do before we act. Most of the time we live in autopilot – engaging in behaviors with little forethought. This can be due to various reasons, for example, the behavior was repeated enough times that it has turned into an automated habit or because you may be seeking instant gratification to feel better (i.e. less bored, distracted etc.). 

One way to manage this is by an exercise that I call ‘Noticing the Urge.’ Many variations of this have been implemented in psychotherapeutic interventions. This is how it goes – when you have the urge to engage in a behavior that you know is not serving you, notice your thought. For example, you may have the thought “I really want to sit here and watch tv instead of exercising.” 

Next, add the phrase “I am noticing I am having the urge!”. This small shift allows you to create a little bit of space between you and your thoughts. And it is in this space that you can choose to pause, think, and respond in a way that aligns with your goals. 

This works because it allows us to accept the thought as it is but also recognize that we do not have to act on every thought we have. There is so much power in that. In fact, this practice can also help build self-confidence because you began to trust yourself more. 

I hope you found this helpful. Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal 

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3062191/

We may not realize when we have weak boundaries if we grew up in an environment where boundaries were rarely respected. It may be difficult for us to identify when we start to feel small, neglected, or resentful because we may have become desensitized to these experiences. 

Repeated experiences in our lives start to feel normal to us even when they are not good for us. As children, if we were not given healthy permission to say no, then we may have difficulty to be okay with saying no in adulthood. If we never learned to take up space, then we may be later challenged to express our opinions and thoughts in a room full of people. If there was no room to talk about our emotions growing up, then it might be hard for us to name what we are feeling and acknowledge it. 

The good news is that we all have the power to change. Our brains create new patterns and behaviors through neuroplasticity. It takes more work on our end initially, but with consistent practice, these behaviors become automatic to us. However, the first step is understanding ourselves better. 

How were your boundaries violated and neglected in the past? How does that impact your ability to set boundaries for yourself?

Shifting our mindset involves challenging negative or unhelpful thoughts (cognitive distortions) and replacing them with more balanced and constructive thoughts. This process helps individuals reinterpret situations more rationally, reducing stress and negative emotional responses.

Because our thoughts influence how we feel and ultimately act, mindset shifts can help us regulate our emotions and get out of a state of paralysis. In cognitive behavioural therapy, we often use the ABC model (Activating event, Beliefs, Consequences) to illustrate how our beliefs about an event influence our emotional and behavioral responses. These mindset shifts target the ‘B’ (Beliefs) part of the model, encouraging more adaptive and constructive beliefs about oneself, situations, or the world, which in turn affect emotional and behavioral outcomes.

In addition, cognitive reframing fosters a sense of self-efficacy by encouraging us to perceive challenges as opportunities for growth. This promotes problem-solving and reduces feelings of helplessness or inadequacy.

When you’re resting but simultaneously experiencing feelings of guilt or shame for not being productive, your brain doesn’t fully enter a state of relaxation or restfulness.

The brain’s default mode network (DMN), responsible for self-reflection, planning, and ruminating thoughts, can be highly activated when you’re engaging in self-criticism about productivity during rest. This activation prevents the brain from entering deeper states of relaxation or restoration. Instead of allowing the brain to rest, these negative thoughts keep certain areas of the brain engaged, consuming mental resources and preventing the restorative processes associated with true relaxation.

Another thing to note is that guilt and shame trigger the release of stress hormones like cortisol, which can further hinder relaxation and contribute to feelings of fatigue. Chronically activating these stress responses during rest can disrupt the body’s natural rhythms and contribute to a persistent feeling of tiredness or lack of energy.

Consequently, this constant mental activity during rest can contribute significantly to feelings of fatigue and tiredness, even though you may have physically been at rest during that time. 

So, next time, allow yourself to consciously disconnect from work-related thoughts and pressures from your daily responsibilities. Understand that rest is a productive activity in itself. Recognize its importance in recharging your mental and physical energy, making you more effective when you’re actively doing those tasks again.

Take care of your mind and body. Love, Nawal ♥️

When someone we care about is going through a difficult time (e.g., heartbreak, relationship difficulties, a personal crisis), they usually are not looking for advice or a solution. But all we want to do is ‘fix’ their problem. This might be because it is difficult for us to acknowledge their pain and sit with it. This is why we often try to ‘force’ them to look at the positive side of things or how what they might be feeling isn’t that bad.

What helps is to offer support in any capacity you can, such as listening to them vent, asking open-ended questions to help them talk through their thoughts, asking them what they need right now, or helping them do everyday tasks that they might be neglecting.
Also, try to avoid relating their situation to a previous experience you had. This is something I learned when I was training to be a therapist. The reason is that it takes away from them talking about their problem and can feel invalidating. But, at the same time, listening to someone else who went through something similar can be helpful for some, as long as you are careful to not pressure them into advice that worked for you during that time.

The reason why I move my body regularly and encourage you to do the same is for cognitive and emotional maintenance. It isn’t to ‘look good’. This isn’t to say you should not have fitness goals, but that shouldn’t be the ultimate outcome when it comes to movement. 

Research has repeatedly shown regular exercise keeps the brain sharp, mood regulated, and stress levels low. Building lean muscle mass also improves hormonal balance which I’ve seen the benefits of first hand as someone with PCOS which makes my body insulin resistance and leads to excessive weight gain. In addition, exercise serves as a buffer for cognitive decline later in life and the muscle strength helps prevents risk of injury from falls. 

When it comes to exercise, do what you can considering your personal circumstances. For example, if you are injured, prioritize rest and recovery first instead of pushing yourself to move. 
Stick to a routine that feels sustainable for you and activities you genuinely enjoy. My favourite way to exercise is weight-lifting at the gym. You do not have to do the same. 

Ways we can move the body include:
Walking
Doing chores
Dancing 
Weight-lifting
Yoga/ Pilates 
Following a full body workout on Youtube
Taking a fitness class


Take care of your mind and body.

Our thoughts shape our reality. In cognitive psychology,  this is known as a confirmation bias, where our brains actively seek evidence that aligns with our beliefs. 

So, if you constantly tell yourself negative things, your brain will work overtime to find proof, creating a self-fulfilling prophecy. 

On the flip side, cultivating positive self-talk can lead to a more optimistic outlook and improved well-being. It’s like a mental filter – focus on the positive, and you’ll start seeing more positivity in your life. 

Remember, the way you talk to yourself can truly mold your experience of the world around you.

I want to add that being positive ALL the time isn’t healthy or human either. While cultivating optimism is valuable, it's essential to recognize and validate negative emotions. Ignoring or dismissing genuine struggles with overly positive statements can be invalidating and counterproductive. Instead, practice mindful positivity by acknowledging challenges, expressing empathy, and then encouraging a constructive mindset. For example, saying, "I understand things are tough right now, and it's okay to feel that way. Let's work on finding a positive perspective together and explore solutions." This approach encourages a more authentic and supportive environment, acknowledging the complexities of emotions while fostering a positive mindset.
